Control: [check11] Avoid the use of the root account
Message: ap-south-1: Root user in the account wasn't accessed in the last 1 days
Risk: The "root" account has unrestricted access to all resources in the AWS account. It is highly recommended that the use of this account be avoided.
Remediation: Follow the remediation instructions of the Ensure IAM policies are attached only to groups or roles recommendation.

Control: [check12] Ensure multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enabled for all IAM users that have a console password
Message: ap-south-1: User prowler has Password enabled but MFA disabled
Risk: Unauthorized access to this critical account if password is not secure or it is disclosed in any way.
Remediation: Enable MFA for root account. MFA is a simple best practice that adds an extra layer of protection on top of your user name and password. Recommended to use hardware keys over virtual MFA.

Control: [check12] Ensure multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enabled for all IAM users that have a console password
Message: ap-south-1: User smash has Password enabled but MFA disabled
Risk: Unauthorized access to this critical account if password is not secure or it is disclosed in any way.
Remediation: Enable MFA for root account. MFA is a simple best practice that adds an extra layer of protection on top of your user name and password. Recommended to use hardware keys over virtual MFA.

Control: [check12] Ensure multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enabled for all IAM users that have a console password
Message: ap-south-1: User testuser has Password enabled but MFA disabled
Risk: Unauthorized access to this critical account if password is not secure or it is disclosed in any way.
Remediation: Enable MFA for root account. MFA is a simple best practice that adds an extra layer of protection on top of your user name and password. Recommended to use hardware keys over virtual MFA.

Control: [check13] Ensure credentials unused for 90 days or greater are disabled
Message: ap-south-1: User prowler has not logged into the console since creation
Risk: AWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials (passwords or access keys). It is recommended that all credentials that have been unused in 90 or greater days be removed or deactivated.
Remediation: Use the credential report to  ensure password_last_changed is less than 90 days ago.

Control: [check13] Ensure credentials unused for 90 days or greater are disabled
Message: ap-south-1: User smash has not logged into the console in the past 90 days
Risk: AWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials (passwords or access keys). It is recommended that all credentials that have been unused in 90 or greater days be removed or deactivated.
Remediation: Use the credential report to  ensure password_last_changed is less than 90 days ago.

Control: [check13] Ensure credentials unused for 90 days or greater are disabled
Message: ap-south-1: User testuser has not logged into the console in the past 90 days
Risk: AWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials (passwords or access keys). It is recommended that all credentials that have been unused in 90 or greater days be removed or deactivated.
Remediation: Use the credential report to  ensure password_last_changed is less than 90 days ago.

Control: [check13] Ensure credentials unused for 90 days or greater are disabled
Message: ap-south-1: User prowler has used access key 1 in the past 90 days
Risk: AWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials (passwords or access keys). It is recommended that all credentials that have been unused in 90 or greater days be removed or deactivated.
Remediation: Use the credential report to  ensure password_last_changed is less than 90 days ago.

Control: [check13] Ensure credentials unused for 90 days or greater are disabled
Message: ap-south-1: User smash has never used access key 1 since creation and not rotated it in the past 90 days
Risk: AWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials (passwords or access keys). It is recommended that all credentials that have been unused in 90 or greater days be removed or deactivated.
Remediation: Use the credential report to  ensure password_last_changed is less than 90 days ago.

Control: [check13] Ensure credentials unused for 90 days or greater are disabled
Message: ap-south-1: User testuser has never used access key 1 since creation and not rotated it in the past 90 days
Risk: AWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials (passwords or access keys). It is recommended that all credentials that have been unused in 90 or greater days be removed or deactivated.
Remediation: Use the credential report to  ensure password_last_changed is less than 90 days ago.

Control: [check13] Ensure credentials unused for 90 days or greater are disabled
Message: ap-south-1: No users found with access key 2 enabled
Risk: AWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials (passwords or access keys). It is recommended that all credentials that have been unused in 90 or greater days be removed or deactivated.
Remediation: Use the credential report to  ensure password_last_changed is less than 90 days ago.

Control: [check14] Ensure access keys are rotated every 90 days or less
Message: ap-south-1: smash has not rotated access key 1 in over 90 days
Risk: Access keys consist of an access key ID and secret access key which are used to sign programmatic requests that you make to AWS. AWS users need their own access keys to make programmatic calls to AWS from the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI)- Tools for Windows PowerShell- the AWS SDKs- or direct HTTP calls using the APIs for individual AWS services. It is recommended that all access keys be regularly rotated.
Remediation: Use the credential report to  ensure  access_key_X_last_rotated  is less than 90 days ago.

Control: [check14] Ensure access keys are rotated every 90 days or less
Message: ap-south-1: testuser has not rotated access key 1 in over 90 days
Risk: Access keys consist of an access key ID and secret access key which are used to sign programmatic requests that you make to AWS. AWS users need their own access keys to make programmatic calls to AWS from the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI)- Tools for Windows PowerShell- the AWS SDKs- or direct HTTP calls using the APIs for individual AWS services. It is recommended that all access keys be regularly rotated.
Remediation: Use the credential report to  ensure  access_key_X_last_rotated  is less than 90 days ago.

Control: [check14] Ensure access keys are rotated every 90 days or less
Message: ap-south-1: No users with access key 2
Risk: Access keys consist of an access key ID and secret access key which are used to sign programmatic requests that you make to AWS. AWS users need their own access keys to make programmatic calls to AWS from the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI)- Tools for Windows PowerShell- the AWS SDKs- or direct HTTP calls using the APIs for individual AWS services. It is recommended that all access keys be regularly rotated.
Remediation: Use the credential report to  ensure  access_key_X_last_rotated  is less than 90 days ago.

Control: [check15] Ensure IAM password policy requires at least one uppercase letter
Message: ap-south-1: Password Policy missing upper-case requirement
Risk: Password policies are used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure password are comprised of different character sets. It is recommended that the password policy require at least one uppercase letter.
Remediation: Ensure "Requires at least one uppercase letter" is checked under "Password Policy".

Control: [check16] Ensure IAM password policy require at least one lowercase letter
Message: ap-south-1: Password Policy missing lower-case requirement
Risk: Password policies are used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure password are comprised of different character sets. It is recommended that the password policy require at least one uppercase letter.
Remediation: Ensure "Requires at least one lowercase letter" is checked under "Password Policy".

Control: [check17] Ensure IAM password policy require at least one symbol
Message: ap-south-1: Password Policy missing symbol requirement
Risk: Password policies are used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure password are comprised of different character sets. It is recommended that the password policy require at least one uppercase letter.
Remediation: Ensure "Require at least one non-alphanumeric character" is checked under "Password Policy".

Control: [check18] Ensure IAM password policy require at least one number
Message: ap-south-1: Password Policy missing number requirement
Risk: Password policies are used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure password are comprised of different character sets. It is recommended that the password policy require at least one uppercase letter.
Remediation: Ensure "Require at least one number " is checked under "Password Policy".

Control: [check19] Ensure IAM password policy requires minimum length of 14 or greater
Message: ap-south-1: Password Policy missing or weak length requirement
Risk: Password policies are used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure password are comprised of different character sets. It is recommended that the password policy require at least one uppercase letter.
Remediation: Ensure "Minimum password length" is set to 14 or greater.

Control: [check110] Ensure IAM password policy prevents password reuse: 24 or greater
Message: ap-south-1: Password Policy missing reuse requirement
Risk: Password policies are used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure password are comprised of different character sets. It is recommended that the password policy require at least one uppercase letter.
Remediation: Ensure "Number of passwords to remember" is set to 24.

Control: [check112] Ensure no root account access key exists
Message: ap-south-1: No access key 1 found for root
Risk: The root account is the most privileged user in an AWS account. AWS Access Keys provide programmatic access to a given AWS account. It is recommended that all access keys associated with the root account be removed. Removing access keys associated with the root account limits vectors by which the account can be compromised. Removing the root access keys encourages the creation and use of role based accounts that are least privileged.
Remediation: Use the credential report to  that the user and ensure the access_key_1_active and access_key_2_active fields are set to FALSE .

Control: [check112] Ensure no root account access key exists
Message: ap-south-1: No access key 2 found for root
Risk: The root account is the most privileged user in an AWS account. AWS Access Keys provide programmatic access to a given AWS account. It is recommended that all access keys associated with the root account be removed. Removing access keys associated with the root account limits vectors by which the account can be compromised. Removing the root access keys encourages the creation and use of role based accounts that are least privileged.
Remediation: Use the credential report to  that the user and ensure the access_key_1_active and access_key_2_active fields are set to FALSE .

Control: [check113] Ensure MFA is enabled for the root account
Message: ap-south-1: MFA is not ENABLED for root account
Risk: The root account is the most privileged user in an AWS account. MFA adds an extra layer of protection on top of a user name and password. With MFA enabled when a user signs in to an AWS website they will be prompted for their user name and password as well as for an authentication code from their AWS MFA device. When virtual MFA is used for root accounts it is recommended that the device used is NOT a personal device but rather a dedicated mobile device (tablet or phone) that is managed to be kept charged and secured independent of any individual personal devices. ("non-personal virtual MFA") This lessens the risks of losing access to the MFA due to device loss / trade-in or if the individual owning the device is no longer employed at the company.
Remediation: Using IAM console navigate to Dashboard and expand Activate MFA on your root account.

Control: [check114] Ensure hardware MFA is enabled for the root account
Message: ap-south-1: MFA is not ENABLED for root account
Risk: The root account is the most privileged user in an AWS account. MFA adds an extra layer of protection on top of a user name and password. With MFA enabled when a user signs in to an AWS website they will be prompted for their user name and password as well as for an authentication code from their AWS MFA device. For Level 2 it is recommended that the root account be protected with a hardware MFA.
Remediation: Using IAM console navigate to Dashboard and expand Activate MFA on your root account.

Control: [check116] Ensure IAM policies are attached only to groups or roles
Message: ap-south-1: prowler has managed policy directly attached
Risk: By default IAM users; groups; and roles have no access to AWS resources. IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended that IAM policies be applied directly to groups and roles but not users. Assigning privileges at the group or role level reduces the complexity of access management as the number of users grow. Reducing access management complexity may in-turn reduce opportunity for a principal to inadvertently receive or retain excessive privileges.
Remediation: Remove any policy attached directly to the user. Use groups or roles instead.

Control: [check116] Ensure IAM policies are attached only to groups or roles
Message: ap-south-1: No policies attached to user smash
Risk: By default IAM users; groups; and roles have no access to AWS resources. IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended that IAM policies be applied directly to groups and roles but not users. Assigning privileges at the group or role level reduces the complexity of access management as the number of users grow. Reducing access management complexity may in-turn reduce opportunity for a principal to inadvertently receive or retain excessive privileges.
Remediation: Remove any policy attached directly to the user. Use groups or roles instead.

Control: [check116] Ensure IAM policies are attached only to groups or roles
Message: ap-south-1: No policies attached to user testuser
Risk: By default IAM users; groups; and roles have no access to AWS resources. IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended that IAM policies be applied directly to groups and roles but not users. Assigning privileges at the group or role level reduces the complexity of access management as the number of users grow. Reducing access management complexity may in-turn reduce opportunity for a principal to inadvertently receive or retain excessive privileges.
Remediation: Remove any policy attached directly to the user. Use groups or roles instead.

Control: [check21] Ensure CloudTrail is enabled in all regions
Message: ap-south-1: No CloudTrail trails were found in the filtered region
Risk: AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls for your account and delivers log files to you. The recorded information includes the identity of the API caller; the time of the API call; the source IP address of the API caller; the request parameters; and the response elements returned by the AWS service.
Remediation: Ensure Logging is set to ON on all regions (even if they are not being used at the moment.

Control: [check23] Ensure the S3 bucket CloudTrail logs to is not publicly accessible
Message: ap-south-1: No CloudTrail trails were found in the account
Risk: Allowing public access to CloudTrail log content may aid an adversary in identifying weaknesses in the affected accounts use or configuration.
Remediation: Analyze Bucket policy to validate appropriate permissions. Ensure the AllUsers principal is not granted privileges. Ensure the AuthenticatedUsers principal is not granted privileges.

Control: [check25] Ensure AWS Config is enabled in all regions
Message: ap-south-1: AWS Config recorder disabled
Risk: The AWS configuration item history captured by AWS Config enables security analysis; resource change tracking; and compliance auditing.
Remediation: It is recommended to enable AWS Config be enabled in all regions.

Control: [check26] Ensure S3 bucket access logging is enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket
Message: ap-south-1: No CloudTrail trails were found in the account
Risk: Server access logs can assist you in security and access audits; help you learn about your customer base; and understand your Amazon S3 bill.
Remediation: Ensure that S3 buckets have Logging enabled. CloudTrail data events can be used in place of S3 bucket logging. If that is the case; this finding can be considered a false positive.

Control: [check27] Ensure CloudTrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs
Message: ap-south-1: No CloudTrail trails were found in the account
Risk: By default; the log files delivered by CloudTrail to your bucket are encrypted by Amazon server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3). To provide a security layer that is directly manageable; you can instead use server-side encryption with AWS KMS–managed keys (SSE-KMS) for your CloudTrail log files.
Remediation: This approach has the following advantages: You can create and manage the CMK encryption keys yourself. You can use a single CMK to encrypt and decrypt log files for multiple accounts across all regions. You have control over who can use your key for encrypting and decrypting CloudTrail log files. You can assign permissions for the key to the users. You have enhanced security.

Control: [check28] Ensure rotation for customer created KMS CMKs is enabled
Message: ap-south-1: This region has no customer managed keys
Risk: Cryptographic best practices discourage extensive reuse of encryption keys. Consequently; Customer Master Keys (CMKs) should be rotated to prevent usage of compromised keys.
Remediation: For every KMS Customer Master Keys (CMKs); ensure that Rotate this key every year is enabled.

Control: [check29] Ensure VPC Flow Logging is Enabled in all VPCs
Message: ap-south-1: VPC vpc-aa9565c1 VPCFlowLog is disabled
Risk: VPC Flow Logs provide visibility into network traffic that traverses the VPC and can be used to detect anomalous traffic or insight during security workflows.
Remediation: It is recommended that VPC Flow Logs be enabled for packet "Rejects" for VPCs.

Control: [check314] Ensure a log metric filter and alarm exist for VPC changes
Message: ap-south-1: No CloudWatch group found for CloudTrail events
Risk: Monitoring unauthorized API calls will help reveal application errors and may reduce time to detect malicious activity.
Remediation: It is recommended that a metric filter and alarm be established for unauthorized requests.

Control: [check36] Ensure a log metric filter and alarm exist for AWS Management Console authentication failures
Message: ap-south-1: No CloudWatch group found for CloudTrail events
Risk: Monitoring unauthorized API calls will help reveal application errors and may reduce time to detect malicious activity.
Remediation: It is recommended that a metric filter and alarm be established for unauthorized requests.

Control: [check38] Ensure a log metric filter and alarm exist for S3 bucket policy changes
Message: ap-south-1: No CloudWatch group found for CloudTrail events
Risk: Monitoring unauthorized API calls will help reveal application errors and may reduce time to detect malicious activity.
Remediation: It is recommended that a metric filter and alarm be established for unauthorized requests.

Control: [check43] Ensure the default security group of every VPC restricts all traffic
Message: ap-south-1: Default Security Groups (sg-0e50af76) found that allow 0.0.0.0 IN or OUT traffic
Risk: Even having a perimeter firewall; having security groups open allows any user or malware with vpc access to scan for well known and sensitive ports and gain access to instance.
Remediation: Apply Zero Trust approach. Implement a process to scan and remediate unrestricted or overly permissive security groups. Recommended best practices is to narrow the definition for the minimum ports required.

Control: [extra711] Check for Publicly Accessible Redshift Clusters
Message: ap-south-1: no Publicly Accessible Redshift Clusters found
Risk: Publicly accessible services could expose sensitive data to bad actors.
Remediation: List all shared Redshift clusters and make sure there is a business reason for them.

Control: [extra713] Check if GuardDuty is enabled
Message: ap-south-1: GuardDuty detector not configured!
Risk: Amazon GuardDuty is a continuous security monitoring service that analyzes and processes several datasources.
Remediation: Enable GuardDuty and analyze its findings.

Control: [extra717] Check if Elastic Load Balancers have logging enabled
Message: ap-south-1: No ELBs found
Risk: If logs are not enabled monitoring of service use and threat analysis is not possible.
Remediation: Enable ELB logging; create la log lifecycle and define use cases.

Control: [extra718] Check if S3 buckets have server access logging enabled
Message: ap-south-1: No S3 Buckets found
Risk: Server access logs can assist you in security and access audits; help you learn about your customer base; and understand your Amazon S3 bill.
Remediation: Ensure that S3 buckets have Logging enabled. CloudTrail data events can be used in place of S3 bucket logging. If that is the case; this finding can be considered a false positive.

Control: [extra735] Check if RDS instances storage is encrypted
Message: ap-south-1: No RDS instances found
Risk: If not enabled sensitive information at rest is not protected.
Remediation: Enable Encryption. Use a CMK where possible. It will provide additional management and privacy benefits.

Control: [extra738] Check if CloudFront distributions are set to HTTPS
Message: ap-south-1: No CloudFront distributions found
Risk: If not enabled sensitive information in transit is not protected. Surveillance and other threats are risks may exists.
Remediation: Use HTTPS everywhere possible. It will enforce privacy and protect against account hijacking and other threats.

Control: [extra740] Check if EBS snapshots are encrypted
Message: ap-south-1: No EBS volume snapshots
Risk: Data encryption at rest prevents data visibility in the event of its unauthorized access or theft.
Remediation: Encrypt all EBS Snapshot and Enable Encryption by default. You can configure your AWS account to enforce the encryption of the new EBS volumes and snapshot copies that you create. For example; Amazon EBS encrypts the EBS volumes created when you launch an instance and the snapshots that you copy from an unencrypted snapshot.

Control: [extra744] Check if API Gateway has a WAF ACL attached
Message: ap-south-1: No API Gateways found
Risk: Potential attacks and / or abuse of service; more even for even for internet reachable services.
Remediation: Use AWS WAF to protect your API Gateway API from common web exploits; such as SQL injection and cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks. These could affect API availability and performance; compromise security; or consume excessive resources.

Control: [extra748] Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 to any port
Message: ap-south-1: No Security Groups found with any port open to 0.0.0.0/0
Risk: If Security groups are not properly configured the attack surface is increased.
Remediation: Use a Zero Trust approach. Narrow ingress traffic as much as possible. Consider north-south as well as east-west traffic.

Control: [extra75] Ensure there are no Security Groups not being used
Message: ap-south-1: sg-0e50af76 is not being used - default security group
Risk: Having clear definition and scope for Security Groups creates a better administration environment.
Remediation: List all the security groups and then use the cli to check if they are attached to an instance.

Control: [extra750] Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 to MySQL port 3306
Message: ap-south-1: No Security Groups found open to 0.0.0.0/0 for MySQL port
Risk: If Security groups are not properly configured the attack surface is increased.
Remediation: Use a Zero Trust approach. Narrow ingress traffic as much as possible. Consider north-south as well as east-west traffic.

Control: [extra751] Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 to Postgres port 5432
Message: ap-south-1: No Security Groups found open to 0.0.0.0/0 for Postgres port
Risk: If Security groups are not properly configured the attack surface is increased.
Remediation: Use a Zero Trust approach. Narrow ingress traffic as much as possible. Consider north-south as well as east-west traffic.

Control: [extra753] Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 to MongoDB ports 27017 and 27018
Message: ap-south-1: No Security Groups found open to 0.0.0.0/0 for MongoDB ports
Risk: If Security groups are not properly configured the attack surface is increased.
Remediation: Use a Zero Trust approach. Narrow ingress traffic as much as possible. Consider north-south as well as east-west traffic.

Control: [extra754] Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 to Cassandra ports 7199 or 9160 or 8888
Message: ap-south-1: No Security Groups found open to 0.0.0.0/0 for Cassandra ports
Risk: If Security groups are not properly configured the attack surface is increased.
Remediation: Use a Zero Trust approach. Narrow ingress traffic as much as possible. Consider north-south as well as east-west traffic.

Control: [extra755] Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 to Memcached port 11211
Message: ap-south-1: No Security Groups found open to 0.0.0.0/0 for Memcached port
Risk: If Security groups are not properly configured the attack surface is increased.
Remediation: Use a Zero Trust approach. Narrow ingress traffic as much as possible. Consider north-south as well as east-west traffic.

Control: [extra773] Check if CloudFront distributions are using WAF
Message: No CloudFront distributions found
Risk: Potential attacks and / or abuse of service; more even for even for internet reachable services.
Remediation: Use AWS WAF to protect your service from common web exploits. These could affect availability and performance; compromise security; or consume excessive resources.

Control: [extra78] Ensure there are no Public Accessible RDS instances
Message: ap-south-1: no Publicly Accessible RDS instances found
Risk: Publicly accessible databases could expose sensitive data to bad actors.
Remediation: Using an AWS Config rule check for RDS public instances periodically and check there is a business reason for it.

Control: [extra780] Check if Amazon Elasticsearch Service (ES) domains has Amazon Cognito authentication for Kibana enabled
Message: ap-south-1: No Amazon ES domain found
Risk: Amazon Elasticsearch Service supports Amazon Cognito for Kibana authentication.
Remediation: If you do not configure Amazon Cognito authentication; you can still protect Kibana using an IP-based access policy and a proxy server; HTTP basic authentication; or SAML.

Control: [extra781] Check if Amazon Elasticsearch Service (ES) domains has encryption at-rest enabled
Message: ap-south-1: No Amazon ES domain found
Risk: If not enable unauthorized access to your data could risk increases.
Remediation: Enable encryption at rest using AWS KMS to store and manage your encryption keys and the Advanced Encryption Standard algorithm with 256-bit keys (AES-256) to perform the encryption.

Control: [extra782] Check if Amazon Elasticsearch Service (ES) domains has node-to-node encryption enabled
Message: ap-south-1: No Amazon ES domain found
Risk: Node-to-node encryption provides an additional layer of security on top of the default features of Amazon ES. This architecture prevents potential attackers from intercepting traffic between Elasticsearch nodes and keeps the cluster secure.
Remediation: Node-to-node encryption on new domains requires Elasticsearch 6.0 or later. Enabling the feature on existing domains requires Elasticsearch 6.7 or later. Choose the existing domain in the AWS console; Actions; and Modify encryption.

Control: [extra783] Check if Amazon Elasticsearch Service (ES) domains has enforce HTTPS enabled
Message: ap-south-1: No Amazon ES domain found
Risk: If not enable unauthorized access to your data could risk increases.
Remediation: When creating ES Domains; enable "Require HTTPS fo all traffic to the domain".

Control: [extra784] Check if Amazon Elasticsearch Service (ES) domains internal user database enabled
Message: ap-south-1: No Amazon ES domain found
Risk: Internal User Database is convenient for demos; for production environment use Federated authentication.
Remediation: Remove users from internal user database and uso Cognito instead.

Control: [extra785] Check if Amazon Elasticsearch Service (ES) domains have updates available
Message: ap-south-1: No Amazon ES domain found
Risk: Amazon ES regularly releases system software updates that add features or otherwise improve your domains.
Remediation: The Notifications panel in the console is the easiest way to see if an update is available or check the status of an update. You can also receive these notifications through Amazon EventBridge. If you take no action on required updates; Amazon ES still updates your domain service software automatically after a certain timeframe (typically two weeks). In this situation; Amazon ES sends notifications when it starts the update and when the update is complete.

Control: [extra787] Check connection and authentication for Internet exposed Elasticsearch/Kibana ports
Message: ap-south-1: No Security Groups found open to 0.0.0.0/0 for Elasticsearch/Kibana ports
Risk: Internet exposed services increases the risk of unauthorised.
Remediation: Placing an Amazon ES domain within a VPC enables secure communication between Amazon ES and other services within the VPC without the need for an internet gateway; NAT device; or VPN connection. All traffic remains securely within the AWS Cloud.

Control: [extra788] Check connection and authentication for Internet exposed Amazon Elasticsearch Service (ES) domains
Message: ap-south-1: No Amazon ES domain found
Risk: Internet exposed services increases the risk of unauthorised.
Remediation: Placing an Amazon ES domain within a VPC enables secure communication between Amazon ES and other services within the VPC without the need for an internet gateway; NAT device; or VPN connection. All traffic remains securely within the AWS Cloud.

Control: [extra798] Check if Lambda functions have resource-based policy set as Public
Message: ap-south-1: No Lambda functions found
Risk: Publicly accessible services could expose sensitive data to bad actors.
Remediation: Grant usage permission on a per-resource basis and applying least privilege principle.
